detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is a synchronous multi-access course. Students are expected to meet on the days and times listed, either in-person or online. All courses labelled ‘multi-access’ offer students the choice of completing the course online, in-person, or using a mix of both. In-person attendance is NOT required, but the option to attend in-person is available. Lectures may be streamed from a classroom and/or uploaded online after class.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

instances.text: PHIL_V 211-001 - Greek Philosophy I: Socrates and Plato

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
PHIL211 is cross-listed with AMNE235. Please register in AMNE235 if PHIL211 is full.  Both courses are identical and fulfilling the same requirements. Philosophy students may register in either PHIL or AMNE.
Course Description: This course traces the early evolution of ancient Greek philosophy, the “love of wisdom” (philosophia), from its roots in Homeric oral poetry (c. 800 BCE) to the Socratic dialogues of Plato (429-347 BCE). We’ll focus on the ancient Greek search for knowledge about nature and the human condition, which many philosophers attributed to an injunction from the Oracle at Delphi: “Know Thyself.” That inquiry unfolded into mythological and scientific speculation about reality and cosmology, human freedom and well-being, and new conceptions of statecraft and justice in cities like Sparta and Athens. 
We’ll trace these themes through Presocratic thinkers like Pythagoras, Thales, Anaximander, and Anaximenes, and explore the insights of women like Aristoclea of Delphi, Diotima of Mantinea, and Perictione of Athens, respectively depicted in Greek literature as teachers of Pythagoras, Socrates, and Plato. According to later sources, their traditions argued for ethical non-violence, sustainable communities, gender equality in education and government, and a theory of stable metaphysical patterns underlying visible reality. These threads converge in Plato’s depiction of Socratic self-cultivation (epimeleia tou heautou), combining novel instruments of rational inquiry with personal inspiration to seek human flourishing (eudaimonia) as a goal of each individual and community.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
DESCRIPTION:
This course will introduce the basic concepts and techniques of First-Order Predicate Logic.  You can get a fairly good sense of the content of the course if you check the Table of Content from the textbook's website (we will try to cover the first 13 chapters -- with some sections skipped).

REQUIRED TEXTS: (available at the Campus Bookstore or electronically) Dave Barker-Plummer, Jon Barwise and John Etchemendy: Language, Proof, and Logic (Second Edition). (with software), CSLI Publications.

Hard copies should be available at the Campus Bookstore. If you want to buy only the online version (electronic copy), you can do it here: <LPL Products Page  Links to an external site.>. Once you have a copy and a Registration ID that comes with it, please login to the Grade Grinder Links to an external site. to register for this course to submit the online HW assignments and to familiarize yourself with the interface and to see how you can follow your own HW submission progress and get other technical support Links to an external site. in case a need arises. (Please read the Introduction of the textbook — in particular pp. 5–10 — for instructions about how to register your copy to use the Grade Grinder at the LPL site.)

GRADING:
Three online term exams:
(Exam dates may change: if they do, advance notification will be given.)
First Exam (20%):       TBA
Second Exam (20%):      TBA
Third  Exam (20%):      TBA
Homework (electronically submitted): 40%

It is always OK to submit or resubmit electronic homework exercises to the Grade Grinder, even if you've passed the due date. Late submissions or corrected resubmissions (after due date) will NOT get huge penalties. We will not accept HW submissions after Dec 17 11:59pm.

Although the reading and HW assignments are posted on Canvas, they are also posted on the LPL site.  It is the LPL site assignments that are official.  So, please, login to the LPL site regularly and follow the reading/HW assignments there.  This is also useful for checking your HW submission progress.

To fully understand the material covered in this course, you need to engage with the material on a weekly basis and do the HW exercises regularly. The material starts easy during the first 2-3 weeks but quickly gets more challenging after that. If you are not regularly keeping up with the course material covered, it will become very difficult for you to catch up later. This is so especially because mastering the later material will require you to know the earlier material well.

FORMAT:
The textbook comes with a software that you will use to study the material and do/submit the assigned homework.   Please register your software to Grade Grinder (read the Introduction of the book for instructions).  The textbook site also allows registered students to watch videos containing lectures by the two authors of the textbook.  You can access these lectures through the "Online Course Material" side tab on the LPL site.   Attending the classes are not mandatory, but highly advised.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This section of PHIL 240 will only involve full class meetings (no discussion section meetings). To register, students must also register for PHIL240.L05, but this “discussion section” will not involve additional scheduled meetings.
Course Description: This course will provide an introduction to epistemology¾the study of how and what we know¾by focusing on the question of trust. We'll ask to what extent we can trust the world, ourselves, other people, and institutions. We'll draw on materials from Classical Sanskrit and contemporary analytic epistemology. This course is in-person and attendance is mandatory.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This section of PHIL 240 will only involve full class meetings (no discussion section meetings). To register, students must also register for PHIL240.L05, but this “discussion section” will not involve additional scheduled meetings.

This is a Synchronous Online course: learning activities that happen at the same time for the instructor and the learners, facilitating real-time interaction between them.

​Instructor: Elena Holmgren

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
